SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 83. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, April 9, 1900.

1. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Sergeant
Charles E. Carpenter, Company D, 27th Infantry, U. S. Vol-
unteers, Manila, Philippine Islands, having accepted a com-
mission as 2d lieutenant in that regiment, will be discharged
the service of the United States by the commanding officer of
his regiment, to date April 2, 1900. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Sergeant
Selwyn D. Smith, Company C, 35th Infantry, U. S. Volunteers,
Manila, Philippine Islands, having accepted a commission as
2d lieutenant in that regiment, will be discharged the service of
the United States by the commanding officer of his regiment,
to date April 2, 1900. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Commis-
sary Sergeant Albert J. Woude, 38th Infantry, U. S. Volun-
teers, Manila, Philippine Islands, having accepted a commis-
sion as 2d lieutenant in that regiment, will be discharged the
service of the United States by the commanding officer of his
regiment, to date January 15, 1900. This soldier is not enti-
tled to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing-named enlisted men, supposed to be at the stations
designated after their respective names, will be discharged by
way of favor from the service of the United States by the
commanding officers of their respective stations:

Recruit Stephen J. Curran, 4th U. S. Infantry, unassigned,
Fort Wood, New York;

Private Charles R. Smith, Company G, 15th U. S. Infantry,
Madison Barracks, New York.
These soldiers are not entitled to travel-pay.

5. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
William Hevie, Troop K, 7th U. S. Cavalry, now at Havana,
Cuba, having enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged
without honor from the service of the United States by the
commanding officer of his station. Under paragraph 1386 of

to exceed ten visits prior to July 1, 1900, from the Frankford
Arsenal, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to the Sandy Hook Prov-
ing Ground, Sandy Hook, New Jersey, on official business per-
taining to meetings of the ordnance board as may be designated
by its president, and on completion of this duty will return to
his proper station after each visit. The travel enjoined is nec-
essary for the public service.

12. First Lieutenant George H. Knox, 7th U. S. Infantry,
will proceed from San Francisco, California, to San Carlos,
Arizona Territory, and join his company. The travel enjoined
is necessary for the public service.

13. Leave of absence for one month is granted 1st Lieuten-
ant George H. Knox, 7th U. S. Infantry.

14. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following-
named officers now on duty at headquarters, Department of
Havana, are relieved from their present duties, to take effect
upon the discontinuance of that department, May 1, 1900:

Lieutenant Colonel Hugh L. Scott, assistant adjutant gen-
eral, U. S. Volunteers, will report in person to the commanding
general, Division of Cuba, for assignment to duty at headquar-
ters of that division;

Major George S. Grimes, 2d U. S. Artillery, will report in
person to the commanding officer of his regiment for duty;

Captain Lawrence B. Simonds, acting judge advocate (1st
lieutenant, 8th U. S. Infantry), will join his company;

Major John T. French, jr., quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers,
after closing up his business as chief quartermaster, Depart-
ment of Havana, will report by cable to the Quartermaster
General, U. S. Army, for further instructions;

Captain Philip Mothersill, assistant commissary of subsist-
ence, U. S. Volunteers, in addition to his present duties, will
report in person to the commanding general, Department of
Havana and Pinar del Rio, for duty as chief commissary of
that department;
✓

Major John F. Stretch, 8th U. S. Infantry, will report in per-
4
son to the commanding general, Division of Cuba, for assign-
ment to duty;

Major William L. Pitcher, 8th U. S. Infantry, will report
in person to the commanding general, Division of Cuba, for
assignment to duty.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

15. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Jefferson
R. Kean, surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, upon being relieved as
chief surgeon, Department of the Province of Havana and
Pinar del Rio, will report in person to the commanding gen-
eral, Division of Cuba, for assignment to duty. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

16. By direction of the Secretary of War, Lieutenant Colonel
John Simpson, deputy quartermaster general, U. S. Army, will
proceed from San Antonio, Texas, to Atlanta, Georgia, on offi-
cial business pertaining to the closing up of the business of the
quartermaster's department at the latter place, and on com-
pletion of this duty will return to his proper station. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

17. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Noble H.
Creager, quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers, will take station in
New York City, New York, until the completion of the repairs
to be made on the transport “McClellan.”
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
Hdqrs of the Army
